title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #1124: Tarski's Circle-Squaring Problem**

Can a circle and square of equal area be decomposed into finitely many congruent pieces?

**Answer: YES** (Laczkovich 1990)

This was one of the most famous problems in geometric measure theory, open from 1925 to 1990. Erdős called it 'a very beautiful problem' and said he would offer $1000 for it.

title: Point
content:
**Point in R²:** A point in 2D Euclidean space.

Defined as `EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)` from Mathlib, providing the standard inner product and norm structure.

title: disk
content:
**Disk of Radius r:** The set {p : ‖p‖ ≤ r}.

A closed disk centered at the origin. This is one of the two shapes in Tarski's problem.

title: square
content:
**Square of Side s:** The set [0,s] × [0,s].

A closed square with corner at the origin. The other shape in Tarski's problem.

title: TranslationCongruent
content:
**Translation Congruence:** Two sets A and B are translation-congruent if B = A + v for some vector v.

Laczkovich's key insight was that translations alone suffice—no rotations or reflections needed!

title: IsDecomposition
content:
**Finite Decomposition:** A partition of set S into finitely many disjoint pieces.

The pieces must be pairwise disjoint and their union must equal S exactly.

title: TranslationEquidecomposable
content:
**Translation Equidecomposable:** Sets A and B can each be decomposed into n pieces such that corresponding pieces are translation-congruent.

This is the key property Laczkovich proved for circles and squares of equal area.

title: SameArea
content:
**Equal Area Condition:** A circle of radius r and square of side s have equal area iff πr² = s².

This is the necessary condition for any equidecomposition to be possible.

title: TarskiProblem
content:
**Tarski's Original Question (1925):** Can a circle and square of equal area be decomposed into finitely many congruent pieces using isometries?

This was open for 65 years until Laczkovich's 1990 solution.

title: laczkovich_theorem
content:
**Laczkovich's Theorem (1990):** YES, and translations alone suffice!

For any circle and square of equal area, there exists a finite decomposition into pieces that can be rearranged by translations only.

**Key facts:**
- Uses approximately 10^50 pieces
- Proof is non-constructive (requires Axiom of Choice)
- Pieces are not Lebesgue measurable

title: laczkovich_piece_count
content:
**Piece Count:** The number of pieces is bounded by 10^51.

The actual number is approximately 10^50—astronomically large but finite. The pieces cannot be explicitly constructed.

title: tarski_solved
content:
**Theorem:** Tarski's problem is solved.

Derived from Laczkovich's theorem: translation equidecomposability implies isometry equidecomposability (translations are isometries).

title: Axiom of Choice
content:
**Non-Constructive Proof:** Laczkovich's proof fundamentally relies on the Axiom of Choice.

The pieces cannot be explicitly constructed—we only know they exist. This connects to the Banach-Tarski paradox.

title: dubins_hirsch_karush
content:
**Dubins-Hirsch-Karush Theorem:** It is impossible to decompose a circle and square into measurable pieces that are translation-congruent.

This explains why Laczkovich's pieces must be non-measurable—the problem has no 'nice' solution.

title: erdos_1124
content:
**Main Result:**
1. Tarski's problem is SOLVED
2. Translations alone suffice (stronger than asked)

This formalizes Erdős Problem #1124 as completely resolved by Laczkovich's 1990 breakthrough.
